summary: These are notes from a November 3, 2021 WebEx meeting with Dr. Rocchio, a forensic psychologist, preparing for an upcoming hearing. The document details her qualifications, expertise in trauma psychology and grooming patterns, and critiques of other experts' work (Dietz and Loftus) in the context of sexual abuse and trafficking cases.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: The subject of the WebEx meeting; her qualifications, training, and expert opinions on trauma, grooming, and memory are reviewed in preparation for a hearing.

persons.name: Dietz
persons.context: Another expert whose work is critiqued by Dr. Rocchio regarding his views on grooming and the reliability of trauma victims' memories.

persons.name: Loftus
persons.context: A memory expert whose laboratory-based research on memory fallibility is discussed and contrasted with the reliability of traumatic memory.

persons.name: Dr. Baily
persons.context: Co-guest editor with Dr. Rocchio on a special issue publication; mentioned in the context of her professional collaborations.

persons.name: Winters
persons.context: A well-respected author cited by Dr. Rocchio regarding literature comparing perpetrators of childhood sexual abuse with sex traffickers.

persons.name: Melissa Farley
persons.context: Cited as a researcher in the area of prostitution and human trafficking whose work informs the understanding of offender patterns.

persons.name: Jennifer Tilde
persons.context: Referenced as an author of literature on 'betrayal trauma,' related to trauma occurring within a trusted relationship.

persons.name: Nicholas Diamond
persons.context: Author of an article titled 'The Truth Is Out There: Accuracy in Recall of Verifiable Real World Events,' cited to counter Loftus's arguments on memory.

persons.name: Allen Batolet
persons.context: Cited as a memory researcher who argues that lab-created memory flaws differ significantly from naturally occurring memory.

connections.description: Dr. Rocchio critiques Dietz's expert opinions on grooming and the reliability of trauma victims' memories, indicating they are part of opposing expert analyses in a legal context.
Dr. Rocchio critiques the applicability of Loftus's laboratory-based memory research to real-world traumatic memory, citing other researchers (Diamond, Batolet) who counter Loftus's points.
Collaborated as invited guest editors on a special issue publication, indicating a professional working relationship.
Dr. Rocchio cites and relies upon the research of Winters, particularly regarding grooming literature and comparisons between child sexual abuse perpetrators and sex traffickers.

events.title: Preparation WebEx with Dr. Rocchio
events.description: A WebEx meeting held to review logistics and prepare Dr. Rocchio for an upcoming hearing, covering her qualifications and expert opinions on trauma, grooming, and memory.

keyFacts: Dr. Rocchio is a forensic psychologist with 15 years of experience, qualified as an expert on traumatic stress and interpersonal violence, and is the President-Elect of the Division of Trauma Psychology.

The document details the concept of 'grooming,' describing it as a process where perpetrators identify, isolate, and build a relationship with a victim for sexual assault, using manipulation and coercion based on a power differential.
Dr. Rocchio critiques memory expert Elizabeth Loftus, arguing that lab-created memory flaws are not directly applicable to the reliable recall of core details in traumatic events.
Dr. Rocchio critiques another expert, Dietz, specifically on his views about grooming and the unreliability of victims' later memories, citing contrary research.
The notes reference a growing body of literature, including work by Winters, that finds common strategies used by perpetrators of childhood sexual abuse and sex traffickers/pimps.
